quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: These things take 6 to 12 months to get them truly robust enough where an important process can be automated.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Sets a practical expectation for enterprise AI timelines before trusting models with mission-critical automation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Like with any of these major tech revolutions, headlines tell one story and then on the ground, laying broadband means you need to dig up every single road in America to lay it. Someone's got to dig up the road or someone's got to run the undersea cable.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that progress depends on unglamorous infrastructure work, not just breakthroughs and hype.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The general trend right now is going from models knowing things to models doing things.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A clear framing shift practitioners can use to prioritize agentic workflows and automation over pure Q&A capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: From an entrepreneurship standpoint, it truly is about what insight do I have? Why am I so lucky to have this insight? Why in a world of a million entrepreneurs who are thinking, who are smart, who are trying everything, why am I in the position where I likely have an insight that others do not?
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A rigorous set of self-questions for validating whether a startup idea is based on a defensible, differentiated insight.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: These tasks now take hours of time and they require PhDs and professionals.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Highlights how frontier model improvement is increasingly driven by high-skill expert work rather than cheap, simple labeling.

quotes.topic_title: Scour lessons: everything is negotiable
quotes.text: I think that the main lesson is that in business and in startups, everything's negotiable.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A simple, reusable mental model for approaching fundraising, partnerships, hiring, and deals as flexible rather than fixed.

quotes.topic_title: Scour lessons: everything is negotiable
quotes.text: And as we were doing the deal, the terms kept changing on us.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A concrete reminder that deal dynamics can shift mid-process, so practitioners should plan for renegotiation and protect leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Scour lessons: everything is negotiable
quotes.text: Oh, you should give us 50% of the company. Oh, you should give us 75% of the company. Oh, if you want to sign the document today, this person's going to show up for breakfast and if you don't sign today and give us 80% of the company, the person's not going to show up.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A vivid example of pressure tactics and moving goalposts in fundraising, useful for recognizing and countering coercive negotiation behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Scour lessons: everything is negotiable
quotes.text: we realized there is no way to do things. There is just the way that you can negotiate your way through the world, which I actually think influenced Travis heavily and then me later heavily at Uber in terms of if you can imagine it and it makes sense and you can align incentives, then it can happen.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A contrarian operating philosophy: outcomes are shaped less by “the right process” and more by negotiation plus incentive alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Scour shutdown and the lawsuit reality check
quotes.text: But we were eventually sued for a quarter of a trillion dollars.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A stark data point illustrating how extreme legal threats can be used as a strategic weapon against startups.

quotes.topic_title: Scour shutdown and the lawsuit reality check
quotes.text: it was just this very cold splash of water about how the real world really works, because the MBAA and the RAA were the ones who sued us, the entertainment industry sued us or the associations that represent the entertainment industry, and then they settled it for $1 million.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Shows the “reality check” that incumbents and their associations can apply overwhelming pressure and still settle for a fraction, implying strategy over damages.

quotes.topic_title: Scour shutdown and the lawsuit reality check
quotes.text: So we're like, "Wait, you wanted a quarter of a trillion dollars and then you settle for $1 million."
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Highlights the mismatch between headline claims and actual outcomes—useful for founders assessing legal threats and negotiating posture.

quotes.topic_title: Scour shutdown and the lawsuit reality check
quotes.text: And of course they were just trying to drive us in a bankruptcy, drive us out of the market, and these are established companies.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: An actionable mental model: interpret some lawsuits as competitive tactics designed to exhaust resources rather than win on merits.

quotes.topic_title: Scour shutdown and the lawsuit reality check
quotes.text: So we're like, "If these guys don't have a playbook to follow, they just make up numbers, then wow, how should we navigate the rest of our lives?"
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A memorable takeaway that challenges the assumption that powerful institutions always operate by consistent rules—prompting more defensive planning.

quotes.topic_title: Scale AI after Meta’s $14B investment
quotes.text: Yeah, so Scale is a fully independent company.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Clarifies the core takeaway of the Meta transaction: Scale’s operating independence remains intact.

quotes.topic_title: Scale AI after Meta’s $14B investment
quotes.text: The transaction was Meta invested a little bit over $14 billion to get 49% of the company, non-voting stock, didn't take a new board seat.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Provides concrete deal structure details that explain why control and governance didn’t shift to Meta.

quotes.topic_title: Scale AI after Meta’s $14B investment
quotes.text: There's no preferential access to anything that Meta has. There's no preferential relationship.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Sets an explicit boundary practitioners can use as a model for structuring strategic investments without exclusivity.

quotes.topic_title: Scale AI after Meta’s $14B investment
quotes.text: And in fact, only about 15 people went over in the transaction.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A specific data point that counters assumptions of a major talent or operational transfer to Meta.

quotes.topic_title: Scale AI after Meta’s $14B investment
quotes.text: So Scale has about 1,100 employees or so now, and we have two major businesses. Each of those businesses, each of them has hundreds of millions of revenue. So we have two unicorns inside the company today that sustains.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Quantifies Scale’s current scale and business composition in a memorable way (“two unicorns inside the company”).

quotes.topic_title: From basic labeling to expert data work
quotes.text: And then, you move forward and the models have gotten better over this period of time. And so, as models get better, they need different types of data. So we've constantly been adapting to the type of data that models need to be successful.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A practitioner-oriented mental model: treat data work as a moving target that must evolve with model capability, not a fixed “labeling” function.

quotes.topic_title: From basic labeling to expert data work
quotes.text: And now, you're at a point where a task is, one task is building an entire website by one of the world's best web developers, or it is explaining some very nuanced topic on cancer to a model. And these tasks now take hours of time and they require PhDs and professionals.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Concrete examples showing the shift from simple preference judgments to high-skill, time-intensive expert tasks—useful for scoping modern data/eval programs.

quotes.topic_title: From basic labeling to expert data work
quotes.text: So to give you a stat to back this up, 80% of the people that we have on our expert network have a bachelor's degree or greater, which is very contrary to some of the positioning that's out there and some of the understanding of this industry. About 15% have a PhD that's greater, and we have PhDs on the network earning significant amounts of money doing labeling, contributing their expertise to these models.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Specific data points that challenge the “low-cost generalist labeling” narrative and quantify how expert-heavy frontier data work has become.

quotes.topic_title: From basic labeling to expert data work
quotes.text: I mean, this game is keeping in touch with the researchers, knowing what they need, coming up with ideas internally.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Actionable operating principle: tight feedback loops with researchers plus internal ideation are core to staying aligned with evolving model needs.

quotes.topic_title: From basic labeling to expert data work
quotes.text: And so, we would go to the model builders and say, "Hey, we noticed that this is a problem. If you would like to fix it, this cadre of experts can do that for you."
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A proactive methodology: identify model failure modes and pitch targeted expert interventions rather than waiting for generic labeling requests.

quotes.topic_title: Recruiting and retaining scarce expert contributors
quotes.text: They are hard to find. You have to have many, many tactics.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A practical recruiting principle: assume no single channel will work for scarce experts and design a multi-pronged sourcing strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Recruiting and retaining scarce expert contributors
quotes.text: The largest way is that they refer each other because when you are enjoying what you're doing and you are using your expertise to contribute to AI, which is pretty cool.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Highlights referrals as the dominant acquisition channel, driven by contributor satisfaction and mission alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Recruiting and retaining scarce expert contributors
quotes.text: We also have campus programs where we will literally go onto the campus and talk to the professors, talk to the students, ask about who would like to do this type of work.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A concrete, replicable tactic for building expert pipelines by recruiting directly through universities and faculty networks.

quotes.topic_title: Recruiting and retaining scarce expert contributors
quotes.text: But the best ones come from these grassroots and referral networks. And the only way you get that is providing a great experience to these people, because these people, they're doing it partly for money, but they're also doing it because they think that their contribution to the AI models is important and interesting, and in many times it solves a problem for them.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A retention-and-growth model: the contributor experience is the engine of network effects and quality in expert marketplaces.

quotes.topic_title: Reinforcement learning environments for AI agents
quotes.text: There's these things called RL environments that effectively are sandboxes for AI agents to play in to accomplish a goal so that they can learn how to accomplish that goal.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Defines a practical mental model for reinforcement learning: build sandboxed environments where agents can safely practice goal completion.

quotes.topic_title: Reinforcement learning environments for AI agents
quotes.text: So for example, you have a Salesforce instance. How does an AI agent navigate that instance? That instance has data that it needs to recognize, it has configurations. Salesforce is a highly configurable product. It has configurations, it needs to understand how to navigate.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Concrete example of why real-world agent training is hard: agents must handle messy data plus highly variable product configurations.

quotes.topic_title: Reinforcement learning environments for AI agents
quotes.text: All of those things need to be trained and there's no alchemy to it. You just have to put the AI agent in an environment that represents what a human being would be doing.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Counteracts “magic” thinking about agent reliability by emphasizing straightforward, environment-based training that mirrors human workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Reinforcement learning environments for AI agents
quotes.text: So what you need is you need a strategy that allows a lab to collect data that is generalizable enough across a broad spectrum of use cases so that they don't have to collect 45 trillion combinations of what should the agent do in this particular situation.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for scaling agent training: prioritize data collection strategies that generalize to avoid combinatorial explosion.

quotes.topic_title: Reinforcement learning environments for AI agents
quotes.text: And the more generalizable it is, the more valuable the data is.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A crisp heuristic for practitioners: optimize for generalizability to maximize the ROI of training data.

quotes.topic_title: What training data looks like in practice
quotes.text: It could be both.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Highlights that training data can include multiple modalities (final artifacts and process traces), not just one fixed format.

quotes.topic_title: What training data looks like in practice
quotes.text: In some cases, it needs to be annotated in such a way that's like, I made this decision for this reason or this decision for that reason, or here's how I would think about it.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Emphasizes adding rationale/decision annotations to make data more useful for training beyond raw outputs.

quotes.topic_title: What training data looks like in practice
quotes.text: So it depends on what the model builders are trying to accomplish.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A practical mental model: choose data format and labeling strategy based on the target capability (e.g., generation vs. debugging).

quotes.topic_title: What training data looks like in practice
quotes.text: So it's not like here's a website and then it's created doing websites. It's like, here's a website, here's why I made this decision, here's why I didn't make this decision, or here's a broken website and here's why it's broken if they're trying to accomplish, I don't know, a debugging tool for a website builder or something like that.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that high-value training data often includes negative decisions and failure analysis, not just successful outputs.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI: healthcare workflow and judgment digitization
quotes.text: Well, we basically built a tool that will read that document for them and point out the top 5 to 10 things that they should take into consideration, either allergies that might not be obvious is one example where we actually, we picked up on an allergy that a patient had that would not have been obvious from reading the document and that allergy actually would've had a conflict with the medication that they were going to be prescribed.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Concrete example of AI augmenting clinician workflow by summarizing massive records and surfacing high-stakes risks (allergy/medication conflicts).

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI: healthcare workflow and judgment digitization
quotes.text: To make this tool better and better, you get to a certain limit with the models off the shelf, and actually the people inside of this healthcare system have to do their own labeling.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Actionable lesson that enterprise AI performance often hits a ceiling without organization-specific labeling by domain experts.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI: healthcare workflow and judgment digitization
quotes.text: One thing people often miss about these systems is we assume because you hear these numbers of like, "Oh, this bank in just 200 petabytes of data a year or whatever fantastical number." What we miss is is that the right data? Which of that data is useful to the models? And most of it is not useful.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Contrarian reminder that data volume is not the bottleneck—data relevance and usability for modeling is.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI: healthcare workflow and judgment digitization
quotes.text: And so, we're getting to the point now where we see that digitizing judgment, human judgment, true subject matter, deep expertise is becoming a bottleneck that we're unblocking for our customers.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Memorable framing of the next enterprise AI constraint: encoding tacit, local expert judgment into systems.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI: healthcare workflow and judgment digitization
quotes.text: And one of the main issues is that a one document, think about the problem of even understanding a document, a document that reads the exact same words in company A will have a different meaning and importance in company B.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Key mental model for why generic AI struggles in enterprises: semantics and priorities are organization-specific even when text is identical.

quotes.topic_title: How long will humans stay in the loop?
quotes.text: First off, the history of data labeling is a history of new beginnings.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A memorable framing that suggests human-in-the-loop work keeps evolving rather than disappearing as models improve.

quotes.topic_title: How long will humans stay in the loop?
quotes.text: Autonomous vehicles do not need as much data labeling as they did in the past.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A concrete example practitioners can use to anticipate how labeling needs shift (not vanish) as systems mature.

quotes.topic_title: How long will humans stay in the loop?
quotes.text: I think we've gotten to a level of advancement in the world that is almost like unfathomable because you're effectively saying that no new human skill and no new human knowledge is important enough to put into these models.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A counterintuitive argument that continued human contribution is implied by the ongoing creation of new knowledge and skills.

quotes.topic_title: How long will humans stay in the loop?
quotes.text: And so, for a business like ours, we're constantly looking at how do you build operations that can constantly find the new needs and then work with the contributor network we call the experts contributors to unearth that data, to unearth that information.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Actionable operational guidance: design processes to continuously discover emerging data needs and mobilize expert networks to fill them.

quotes.topic_title: How long will humans stay in the loop?
quotes.text: So I think what we're underestimating in all of the doom and gloom is we believe in human adaptability.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A practical mental model for workforce planning: assume roles will change and people will adapt rather than be rapidly displaced.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: defining what “good” looks like
quotes.text: A lot of it's evals, and within enterprise customers and government customers, it's mostly evals because somebody's got to establish the benchmark for what good looks like. That's the simple way to think about evals. What does good look like and do you have a comprehensive set of evals so that the system knows what good looks like? It's as simple as that.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Defines evals as the practical mechanism for specifying quality standards, especially in high-stakes enterprise/government settings.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: defining what “good” looks like
quotes.text: these are probabilistic systems and so depending upon... Yeah, so I can get into some nuance here about the right types of problems that AI is good at solving. So if you have a human process that is 10 or 20% accurate or 10 or 20% liked, AI is awesome. Because if you get to 50, 60, 70, 80% accurate, you're in the money, you're in the green, everybody's happy.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Offers a selection heuristic: AI delivers outsized value when it can lift low-performing workflows into a “good enough” range.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: defining what “good” looks like
quotes.text: If you have a human process, a workflow that is 98% accurate, and you expect an AI system to get you the remaining 2%, not totally there yet.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that the last-mile accuracy in already-high-performing workflows is the hardest part to automate with AI.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: defining what “good” looks like
quotes.text: Now, the system then has to know, hey, for the remainder, how do I make sure that humans are involved for the remainder of the decision making?
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Highlights an operational design requirement: build explicit handoff/oversight paths for cases the model can’t confidently handle.

quotes.topic_title: Evals: defining what “good” looks like
quotes.text: What you're looking for is you're looking for the best recommendation or course of action given the current information.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Reframes “correctness” as decision quality under uncertainty—useful for designing evals around recommendations, not just right answers.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI is heading: from knowing to doing
quotes.text: The general trend right now is going from models knowing things to models doing things.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A simple framing practitioners can use to evaluate AI roadmaps: shift focus from knowledge benchmarks to real-world task execution.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI is heading: from knowing to doing
quotes.text: And as soon as you get into that world, that's where the environments we were talking about start to come into play. How do you navigate a Salesforce instance? How do you navigate a healthcare system? How do you navigate even a weather app on your phone, and how does the agent make decisions for you?
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Makes “agents” concrete by pointing to specific operational environments teams can target for automation and evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI is heading: from knowing to doing
quotes.text: People take different trajectories on how that's going to improve.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A useful mental model for planning: expect wide variance in timelines and outcomes because the field is at the beginning of action-taking systems.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI is heading: from knowing to doing
quotes.text: There's still people in the world without an email address. And so, the adoption curve then becomes a human and policy issue, not a technological issue.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that deployment bottlenecks often come from change management and governance rather than model capability.

quotes.topic_title: Where AI is heading: from knowing to doing
quotes.text: We're not there from the technology standpoint, but I do think in the next two to three years, if I take the bait and have to make a guess is the technology will get to a point where it will push the change management and policy makers to say like, "Oh, what do we do with this because it's getting pretty close?"
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A concrete time horizon practitioners can use for scenario planning: tech may soon outpace organizational and policy readiness.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI reality: pilots, hype, and timelines
quotes.text: But basically what happens is the POCs get to 60 or 70% of the way there, and the human mind goes, oh, the rest is no big deal.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Highlights the common enterprise trap where early AI prototype success masks the hardest reliability and operational work needed for production.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI reality: pilots, hype, and timelines
quotes.text: But it's like uptime in data centers where every nine is an order of magnitude investment in terms of reliability, backups, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Provides a memorable mental model for why moving from “mostly works” to “production-grade” requires disproportionately more effort.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI reality: pilots, hype, and timelines
quotes.text: if you take the efforts that happen in the company where they actually get a quality partner like we are, or if you do it yourself, if you have engineers who've worked with models before and they put in the time, and I'm talking about months, not like minutes like you see in these videos to actually get legal approval, policy approval, regulatory approval, change managements like an accuracy that everybody's comfortable with.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Emphasizes that real enterprise AI success depends as much on approvals and change management as on model performance—and it takes months.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI reality: pilots, hype, and timelines
quotes.text: If you actually do that, these things take 6 to 12 months to get them truly robust enough where an important process can be automated.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Sets a concrete, practitioner-relevant timeline for turning AI pilots into robust automation for critical workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Enterprise AI reality: pilots, hype, and timelines
quotes.text: Easy to learn, hard to master. That's my summary.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A succinct takeaway that reframes enterprise AI as a mastery problem (operationalization and reliability), not a demo problem.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Sending wires, tracking spend, giving people on my team access to move money around so freaking easy.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights concrete, operational banking workflows teams can streamline (wires, spend tracking, delegated access).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Where most traditional banking websites and apps are clunky and hard to use, Mercury is meticulously designed to be an intuitive and simple experience.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A product principle: usability and thoughtful design can be a differentiator in traditionally clunky categories.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And Mercury brings all the ways that you use money into a single product, including credit cards, invoicing, bill pay, reimbursements for your teammates and capital.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A bundling mental model—consolidating adjacent financial workflows into one system to reduce tool sprawl.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're a funded tech startup looking for ways to pay contractors and earn yield on your idle cash, or an agency that needs to invoice customers and keep them current, or an e-commerce brand that needs to stay on top of cashflow and access capital, Mercury can be tailored to help your business perform at its highest level.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Gives specific use cases across business types, mapping features to outcomes (yield, invoicing, cashflow, capital).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: See what over 200,000 entrepreneurs love about Mercury.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete adoption data point that signals scale and social proof.

quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and incentives-driven product discovery
quotes.text: I don't take what a customer says literally.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A crisp reminder that effective customer discovery focuses on underlying needs rather than surface-level feature requests.

quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and incentives-driven product discovery
quotes.text: I look at the underlying incentives of the customer.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A practical framework for interpreting customer feedback through incentive structures (not just stated preferences).

quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and incentives-driven product discovery
quotes.text: I'm a big believer that it's cliche, but show me the incentive and I'll show you the outcome.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for predicting behavior and designing products/rollouts that align stakeholder motivations.

quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and incentives-driven product discovery
quotes.text: So, what we did is we ordered just a bunch of food from these places, and then we got a restaurant supplier to give us a base catalog, and we just matched up how much does the ham weigh? How much does the cheese weigh? How much does the bread weigh? How many pieces of lettuce were on there? And we tried to actually just compose our own independent view of what's the ingredients cost versus what's the labor cost?
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: A concrete, scrappy methodology for reverse-engineering customer unit economics when direct access or trust is limited.

quotes.topic_title: Customer obsession and incentives-driven product discovery
quotes.text: Well, what we found as part of this is that roughly a restaurant pays 20 to 30% of every meal to ingredients, and they pay roughly 20 or 30% to labor, and they pay roughly 10% to real estate and a bunch of other, anyway, so goes down the chain.
quotes.speaker: Jason Droege
quotes.context: Specific unit-economics benchmarks that inform pricing, take-rate strategy, and the value of incremental demand for restaurants.
